explanation: lfs_mkdir calls lfs_mkdir_, so lfs_mkdir_ must be inspected for any use of memcmp on null-terminated strings (direct or indirect). lfs_mkdir_’s callees (lfs_fs_forceconsistency, lfs_dir_find, lfs_path_islast, lfs_path_namelen, lfs_alloc_ckpoint, lfs_dir_alloc, lfs_dir_fetch, lfs_pair_tole32, lfs_dir_commit, lfs_pair_fromle32, lfs_fs_preporphans) are included because any of these functions may perform name/path comparisons or otherwise call memcmp improperly; directory/path helpers (lfs_dir_find, lfs_path_islast, lfs_path_namelen) are especially likely to compare string names and must be checked. LFS_LOCK, LFS_UNLOCK and LFS_TRACE macros/functions used in the target should be examined as well (they could expand/call code that uses memcmp or string comparisons). Finally, the standard symbol memcmp is included so the analyzer can detect direct uses and verify whether it is being (mis)used to compare null-terminated strings. Inspecting these symbols provides coverage of all code reachable from lfs_mkdir that could violate the MISRA rule.
